keyTakeAways: Thousands of residents in Catanduanes, a Philippine island, evacuated due to Tropical Storm Fengshen approaching the coast.
The storm brings heavy rainfall and a minimal to moderate risk of coastal flooding from waves up to 1.2 meters high.
More than 9,000 people moved to safer areas, following a recurring evacuation drill that has historically been effective in saving lives.
Catanduanes is one of the first landmasses affected by storms forming in the western Pacific Ocean, making it a key area for early warning and disaster preparedness.
The Philippines experiences an average of 20 storms and typhoons annually, primarily affecting impoverished, disaster-prone communities.
Scientists attribute increasing storm intensity to human-driven climate change, which is altering the frequency and strength of tropical cyclones.
The country is still recovering from previous disasters, including deadly earthquakes and typhoons, which have added to public trauma and infrastructure strain.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Thousands of residents in the Philippine island of Catanduanes have evacuated their homes as Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches, with forecasted strong winds and a risk of coastal flooding from waves up to 1.2 meters high. The province has activated evacuation plans for vulnerable areas, including coastal zones and landslide-prone slopes, following a routine drill that has historically protected lives. This event occurs amid a broader pattern of recurring disasters, including deadly earthquakes and typhoons, which have recently overwhelmed communities. Scientists link the increasing intensity of storms to climate change, and the Philippines, already vulnerable due to its geographic location and poverty levels, continues to face mounting risks from natural disasters.
title: Thousands evacuate Philippine coast as Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches
